Award.AwardTitle: Educational supplement for the 30th Summer Symposium in Molecular Biology

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
The 30th Penn State Summer Symposium in Molecular Biology will be held June 21-24, 2011 at University Park, PA. The topic of this symposium is "Chromatin and Epigenetic Regulation of Transcription". The symposium will cover chromatin organization and the mechanistic basis for genetic and epigenetic regulation of transcription. The session topics are as follows: Genomics, Nuclear Organization, Chromatin Mechanisms, Epigenetics, and Elongation Control. The roster of 22 invited speakers is composed of internationally acclaimed scientists who lead research in the field of chromatin structure and epigenetics. The unique intellectual strength of the Penn State Summer symposium is that it is combines the top scientific level of the meeting with location at a big University campus that makes it readily accessible to a wide body of graduate, undergraduate, and high school students undergoing summer training at the Penn State Hershey and University Park campuses. A group of faculty at Pennsylvania State University have assembled a list of 22 invited speakers with an additional 30 oral presentations selected from submitted abstracts.

Broader Impacts
The summer symposium will provide a vehicle for exchange of information between scientists at Penn State and other institutions. It is financially accessible to undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, who comprise about 75% of attendees. Many of these students are members of underrepresented groups or represent rural areas in central Pennsylvania. The plenary lecture is open to the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chromatin and Epigenetic Regulation of Transcription is one of the most rapidly developing areas of contemporary biology. The overall goal of this educational supplement was to strengthen the educational function of the 30th Penn State Summer Symposium in Molecular Biology on “Chromatin and Epigenetic Regulation of Transcription” that was held on June 21 - 24, 2011 at the University Park campus of the Pennsylvania State University. The unique intellectual merit of the Penn State Summer Symposium is that it is combines the top scientific level of the meeting with a location at a big university campus that makes it readily accessible to a wide body of graduate and undergraduate students.

The specific objective of the project supported by NSF was to strengthen educational learning opportunities and increase the diversity of participants at the 30th Penn State Summer Symposium in Molecular Biology. We  advertised the Symposium for high school and undergraduate students participating in various summer research training programs at Penn State and provided all high school and undergraduate students access to all sessions for a $25 fee.  To stimulate interactions of students and postdoctoral scholars with the invited speakers (all of whom were internationally renowned scientists leading the field of chromatin and epigenetic regulation of transcription), we organized an informal Wednesday boxed lunch discussion session. To accommodate the anticipated attendance and create an environment that promotes scientific information sharing, we rented a professional, theater style auditorium, reserved lounge space for the public plenary lecture reception and discussions, and provided wireless access accounts for non-Penn State University attendees. The registrants included 32% faculty/researchers/non-academic employees, 22% postdoctoral scholars and technicians, 43% graduate students, and 3% undergraduate students. 66% of the registrants were not from the Pennsylvania State University. We received 132 abstracts for the poster presentation session (highest number in the symposium’s 30 year history).

At the end of the 2011 symposium, feedback from attendees was collected, compiled, and shared with organizers to aid in planning future symposia. Based on the evaluations provided by the conference participants, we believe that we achieved a goal of creating the dynamic, interactive atmosphere desired by both speakers and participants and strengthening the educational function of the 30th Penn State Summer Symposium. In particular, 96% of the Symposium respondents either agreed or strongly agreed to the survey statement “Overall, I was very satisfied with the quality of this educational experience”. 93% agreed or strongly agreed to the survey statement “The value of the educational experience was worth the price of the Symposium”.
